content: Are you using a Pop account in Thunderbird ? I'm assuming the answer is yes. Did you access webmail and read those few emails that did not get downloaded to pop account ? If yes, then logon to webmail account: Make sure those emails are in the 'Inbox' as pop can only acces Inbox and also set those emails as 'unread', then in Thunderbird, click on 'Get Messages'.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
There are many ways to delete an email and I'm none the wiser on what you are doing, so I'll offer a list of various methods. Please note: do not attempt to delete or indeed do anything whilst Thunderbird is compacting - wait until it has finished.

  1. Select email in list so it is open and you can read it in Message Pane - click on the 'Delete' button in the Message Header area.
  2. Right click on email in Message List and click on the Trash bin icon located top right
  3. Select email in list and use the Menu Bar toolbar - select 'Edit' > click on 'Delete Message'
  4. Select email in list and use Menu bar via keyboard 'Alt E' and then 'D'
  5. Select email in list and press the 'Delete' key on keyboard.
  6. In Table View - Enable the 'Delete' column header so you see a grey trash bin icon adjacent to each email in list - click on the relevant bin icon to delete message.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
It would be useful to know where you are trying to delete an email.

Are you talking about a folder and email in a POP or IMAP account or Local Folders account ? Are you talking about email in a normal folder OR a 'Unified' folder which you may see if using 'View' > 'Folders' > 'Unified folders'? Is the email in a default folder or a folder you created ? Are you having a problem with just one particular email or is this a problem with deleting any email ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Thunderbird is only reporting the feedback from server. The servers are selected by account, not by password. if the account uses 'app' passwords, such as Gmail, the normal password doesn't work.
creator: davidsk

content: Normally, this should not be a probiem, as the ...appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.ini file should be pointing to the correct profile, wherever it is. Installing thunderbird should not change that setting.
creator: davidsk

content: You need to contact email provider for a new password or retrieve old password there. Thunderbird only holds whatever password you provide to it.
creator: davidsk

content: The email address in incoming pane is not the same as in smtp server pane. the incoming is dpace4114@ and the smtp is danielpace4114@ Fix that and try again.
creator: davidsk

content: My guess is that you are using the same SMTP server for both. To verify, edit the SMTP server for each by changing DESCRIPTION field to contain the email address. Then, click the account settings>server settings pane for each and look at bottom line to see the email address shown in the link to SMTP server.
creator: davidsk

content: That is one reason I prefer to copy profiles instead of manually entering account info. All I can suggest is to post screenshots of incoming server setting pane and SMTP server settings pane and complete text of any error messages. With that, someone here may have suggestions. Thank you
